Hi Dianna,
MY HYPOTHESIS ON THE CREATION OF OUR UNIVERSE.
About 30+ years or so ago I learned that the way the universe moved and reacted indicated that there was something else acting upon it and cosmologists coined the term "Dark Matter" to account for this. This "Invisible stuff" was said to make up 95% of the known universe and it accounted for the way galaxies etc moved. Saying that 95% of the visible universe wasn't there was to say somewhat overwhelming and confusing. Essentially my thoughts on the creation of the Universe still agreed with the current theory of the big bang.


Now my thoughts and feelings begin.
I have always had this problem with the concept that the Universe and time began from nothing, "something from nothing"..............that doesn't work for me. So, what was the singularity that our Universe was formed from made of ?
Time was said not to exist before the big bang, nothing existed. Well what if something did ? My thoughts are this.
Before the big bang there was, (this is now my terminology) The Dark Universe. This consisted totally of dark matter and it is uniforme in nature, there was no light but this matter has exactly the same properties and gravitational values as our Universe. This Dark Universe's size in comparison to our Universe is massive. Somehow some of this dark matter coalesced to form an exceptionally dense region, this area continued to become more dense and this is what ultimately went on to become the singularity that formed the big bang. The "Big bang" went on to produce "New Matter". This matter went on to produce light an I now use the term the "Light Universe".

The Light Universe then inflated as we have theorised and gone on to form our "Known Universe". The Dark Universe is still there, unchanged and gravitationally acting on our now Light Universe, It is essentially the fabric or foundation of our Light Universe. It provides that extra impetus on the galaxies etc that make up our Universe.

As I hypothesised earlier, the Dark Universe is huge, so massive that it would allow for multiple Light Universes. In fact it could well be millions or billions of them.

Another thought on the consequences of this is the problem of the unification of the theories of Quantum Theory and Einstein's theories of relativity. Just perhaps Quantum theory may relate to the Dark Universe and it's atomic structure and Einstein's theories may relate to the Light Universe, but that is way out of what I can understand.
I would love a reply to this with your thoughts Dianna, even if it is to say that I have no idea of what I am talking about.

I have NEVER liked physics. 🥺 I wish that this channel would have been around in high school and while I struggled (horribly) with my physics classes in college. What is physics?  It's basically just the application of mathematics and the scientific method to understanding the world around us.  Honestly, 85% of it is algebra, and about 14% is common sense.  (The other 1% is mostly higher-level abstract math, stuff you can't even take until you've got at least a year of college calculus under your belt first, and this is the stuff that can be rather counterintuitive; this is where stuff like quantum mechanics and fluid dynamics are found, and the rabbit hole goes very deep.)

I got along well with almost all my teachers in high school, but for some reason my physics teacher really didn't like me.  But I recall many of the girls in my class REALLY didn't like him.  More than one female student told me he was "really pervy."  Some 20 years later, I decided to enter the NYC Teaching Fellows Program.  It's a program where you take education courses over a summer and get provisional certification as a teacher.  One of the girls in my group had also gone to the Bronx High School of Science, but had just graduated college so she had attended quite a while after me.  That combined with how large the school is meant we didn't have many teachers in common.  But I mentioned my physics teacher and she went "Oh Yes.  What a PERV."  It was at that moment I made up my mind to never be known as a pervy teacher.  But that is a long way to say I would much rather have had Diana as a physics teacher.  But as I took Physics 35 years ago, I may not have learned much as I don't think she had been born yet.

Physics is the study of the fundamental mechanics of the physical universe. It's the most fundamental of the natural sciences. Chemistry is a higher-order science dealing with the behavior and interactions of materials and substances - which is ultimately dictated by physics happening at the atomic and molecular level. Biology is an even higher-order science dealing with complex chemical systems - called life. It's basically nature's technology leveraging chemistry and physics. Psychology is a still even higher-order science dealing with mind states and resultant behaviors of complex living systems. Mind is a function of the brain which is based on Biology. Physics --> Chemistry --> Biology --> Psychology. It all ultimately boils back down to Physics.

Ma'am. Please make a video on scientific achievements of ancient Indians. Nobody except we Indians speak about this. Please help us regain our lost pride. Actually, we Indians had known thousands of astronomial information more than 3000-4000 years back. We knew that Earth revolves the sun (which was earlier thought to be geocentric), we knew astronomial time spans, the circumference and radius of Earth, the big bang, the 9 planets, a few major stars, the distance between Moon and Earth (measured using trigonometry), and also knew that Earth was not flat 🤣🤣
apart from astronomy, Indians had huge contributions to science and mathematics before 3 millennia.

Mathematics: the idea of zero, Decimal system, the Pythagorean theorem, numeral notation, Fibonacci and Tribonacci numbers, binary system, use of rulers (measurement), sign conventions, Pascal's triangle, value of pi(π), trigonometric identities and functions, sets and subsets, coordinate and practical geometry etc.

Science: structure of an atom, smelting of zinc, cloning, plastic surgery, cataract surgery, Ayurveda, rocket propellants, Siddha medicines, cure for leprosy, the idea of gravity etc.

And you won't believe this: there is a temple (named Varamurtheeswarar temple) in my state named Tamil Nadu which is claimed to be around 6000 years old. In the wall of the temple, there are detailed sculptures depicting the exact shapes, positions and sizes during fetal development. And they have been approved by doctors. We Indians knew the science of fetal formation and development without any scanning device
